summary: As U.S. President Barack Obama arrives in Indonesia for a series of summits, Southeast Asia is hoping the U.S. will take further steps to tighten economic ties with the region.

headline: Concealed-Weapons Bill Passes in House
summary: House lawmakers easily approved legislation that would require states to observe concealed-weapons permits issued by other state governments in a victory for Second Amendment champions in Congress.

summary: A Nevada grand jury has handed up criminal indictments against two title officers employed by Lender Processing Services for allegedly directing and supervising a robo-signing scheme, in which documents filed in foreclosure cases were signed without proper legal review.

summary: A Democratic candidate for Pennsylvania attorney general will propose ways of fixing what he calls a systemic failure to protect children from sexual abusers in the state.

summary: A man shaves a fellow villager's head with a sickle in China, schoolgirls hug U. S. President Obama in Australia, Indians attend an annual cattle fair and more.

headline: Singapore October Exports Plunge
summary: Singapore's key non-oil exports fell across all major segments in October, raising the odds of the country's economy slipping back into contraction in the fourth quarter.

headline: Oil Jumps on Pipeline Deal
summary: Canada's Enbridge will buy a 50% stake in a pipeline currently moving oil from the Gulf Coast to Oklahoma -- and then plans to reverse the flow. The move could ease a bottleneck of crude in the Midwest.

headline: Former Madoff Trader Plans to Plead Guilty
summary: David L. Kugel is expected to plead guilty next week to conspiracy and other charges in the multibillion-dollar fraud, prosecutors said.

headline: Toyota, Subaru Expected to Hold Value
summary: The Toyota and Subaru brands are likely to retain their value better than other brands after several years, according to two forecasts.

headline: Chesapeake Plans Oil-Field Services Spinoff in 2012
summary: Chesapeake Energy plans to spin off its oil-field-service business next year in a public stock offering to establish the value of the unit to investors, Chief Executive Aubrey McClendon said.

headline: MF Trustee Revises Its Trapped-Account Estimate
summary: The office of the trustee unwinding MF Global's brokerage, James W. Giddens, on Wednesday offered an update on the accounts it is handling, with some figures less than previously stated.

headline: Chinese Firm Bids for Jaguar Mining
summary: State-owned Shandong Gold of China has offered to buy Brazilian gold miner Jaguar Mining for $1 billion.

headline: Dodgers Sue Fox Sports
summary: The Los Angeles Dodgers sued Fox Sports in bankruptcy court for allegedly interfering with the team's bid to sell its valuable broadcast rights.

headline: A New Day in Myanmar?
summary: Myanmar's military-aligned government has pledged to loosen the hard-line policies of the junta that preceded it and is seeking the chairmanship of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in 2014. See scenes from the capital.

headline: Tokyo, Osaka Exchanges Near Merger Deal
summary: Japan's two largest stock exchanges are expected to clinch a merger agreement as early as next week.

headline: China at 'Critical Juncture,' Alice Waters Says
summary: For Alice Waters, buying organic food in China isn't as difficult as she thought it would be.

summary: The head of the International Monetary Fund's European department resigned suddenly on Wednesday, leaving the fund at a critical time as it grapples with the European financial crisis.

summary: The euro struggled to break out of its current range versus the dollar, with investors still wary about the ongoing debt crisis in Europe.

headline: Tibetan Abbot Blames Immolations on Chinese Policies
summary: A recent spate of self-immolations among Tibetans will continue as long as the Chinese government maintains its repressive policies in the region, according to the exiled head of a Tibetan monastery that has been at the center of the unprecedented wave of almost a dozen such protests since March.

headline: Credit Suisse Moves on New York City Job Cuts
summary: Credit Suisse has begun the job cuts it warned about earlier this month, planning to eliminate 268 jobs in the New York metropolitan region.

headline: BNP Paribas to Cut Jobs
summary: BNP Paribas said that it plans to cut almost 1,400 jobs, or close to 7% of staff, at its corporate and investment bank in response to Europe's deepening sovereign-debt crisis.

headline: Lawmakers Voice Piracy-Bill Support
summary: Many lawmakers on the House Judiciary Committee expressed support for new legislation aimed at cutting off funding to foreign websites offering pirated movies or counterfeit goods, despite opposition from Silicon Valley companies.

headline: Youth Hit as U.K. Jobless Rate Rises
summary: U.K. unemployment rose again in October, while the number of young people without a job topped one million at the end of September.

summary: Turkey said it expected to sign a deal next week with Royal Dutch Shell to conduct oil and natural-gas exploration in the Mediterranean.

summary: Gold prices slumped as U.S. inflation eased in October and as a steady dollar damped demand for the precious metal as a currency alternative.

summary: The London Stock Exchange, despite challenging conditions for equity markets, has found a lucrative alternative source of revenue: lending money to Italian banks.

headline: Poll Finds Germans Backing Euro
summary: More than three out of five Germans give their government poor marks for its handling of the European financial crisis, but about the same proportion see the euro remaining Germany's currency 10 years from now, according to results from the GfK Investment Barometer survey.

headline: BMW Plans Corporate Car Sharing Program
summary: BMW plans to launch next year a business-focused car-sharing program called AlphaCity aimed at reducing the costs of large company fleets.

summary: The Blue Devils' Mike Krzyzewski reigns supreme as NCAA Division I's winningest basketball coach, surpassing his former coach and mentor, Bob Knight, with a win over Michigan State at Madison Square Garden.

summary: Hungary's weakening currency and rising borrowing needs have swollen its debt load to 82% of gross domestic product, overshooting government fiscal targets.

summary: Euro contagion isn't confined to the currency bloc. Hungary's currency, the forint, has fallen 16% against the euro since early September amid concerns over exposure to European banks and export markets.

headline: Germany Looks Isolated on Crisis Plans
summary: Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny called for allowing the ECB to play a greater role in preventing the spread of financial turmoil in Europe. But German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schäuble disagreed.

summary: The London Stock Exchange Group posted an 87% rise in first-half net profit, helped by a strong performance of its post-trade business.

Still, signs of economic weakness in the U.K., together with worries about funding for Italian lender UniCredit, added to pressure on markets.

headline: Brazil Oil Workers to Meet to Review Possible Strike
summary: Leaders of the Brazilian Oil Workers Federation will meet Nov. 22 to review wage and benefit negotiations with state-run energy company Petrobras and set a date for a possible nationwide strike.

headline: Euro-Zone Bonds Come Unstuck
summary: Europe's bond markets are in meltdown. As investors lose confidence, bonds may be starting to price in extreme outcomes such as a euro-zone break-up.

summary: Samsung, the world's biggest technology company by revenue, has acquired a U.S. health-care equipment maker in its latest effort to expand business overseas.

summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

summary: One of the more pressing challenges in U.S.-Vietnam trade concerns American protectionism against a fish, the pangasius, which accounts for 2% of Vietnam's GDP.

headline: Contemplating a Career in Nonprofits?
summary: Corporate workers may be lured by the idea of 'making a difference' at a nonprofit, but with long hours and often lower pay, the switch is often easier said than done.

headline: Bundesbank Slams Crisis Proposals
summary: Germany's powerful Bundesbank issued a stark rebuke of the euro zone's response to the debt crisis, dismissing several recent proposals aimed at calming markets and bolstering the currency bloc's bailout fund.

headline: London to Seek Eviction of Occupy Protesters
summary: City's announcement comes as protesters head for U.S. Embassy, where they plan to protest the forcible removal of the Occupy Wall Street camp.

summary: Iincyte's Jakafi pill obtained FDA approval, making it the first drug approved specifically for myelofibrosis, a rare bone-marrow disease.

headline: CFTC's Gensler Defends Client Fund Segregation
summary: CFTC Chairman Gary Gensler said the model of walling off customer money from that of big derivatives brokers remains at the heart of U.S. market regulation, despite charges the practice failed MF Global clients.

headline: IPO Rush in Hong Kong
summary: Despite volatility that has made investors wary of buying, a wave of companies are hurrying to complete initial public offerings here, pushing the local exchange's listing committee to take extra steps to clear the backlog.

headline: Airbus, Boeing Share Gulf Orders
summary: Gulf airlines showed few signs of tightening their purse strings at the 2011 Dubai Air Show, defying an uncertain global economic environment.

headline: Regulator to Order Lone Star to Sell KEB Stake
summary: South Korea's financial regulator will issue an order Friday to Lone Star to sell its majority stake in KEB, clearing the way for a sale to Hana Financial. The question now is whether the regulator will attach a penalty to the sale order.

summary: Foreign-exchange options are sending out strong signals that investors expect a sharp fall in the euro's value against the dollar over the next month, with a key benchmark fear gauge breaching record highs Wednesday.

headline: Clinton Seeks Peaceful End to Sea Dispute

headline: Infineon Expects Falling Sales
summary: German chip maker Infineon Technologies expects sales to fall by a mid-single digit percentage this fiscal year as caution among customers increases.

summary: Tyco's fiscal-fourth-quarter earnings rose 50% as the conglomerate generated stronger revenue across its main businesses and incurred fewer charges.

headline: Giffords at Work
summary: Rep. Gabrielle Giffords was first elected to Congress in 2006 after serving in the Arizona state House and Senate. See highlights of her career before and after an assassination attempt on her life.

headline: Euro-Zone Inflation Stable
summary: The euro zone's annual inflation rate was stable at 3% in October, unchanged from the previous month's three-year high due to increases in energy costs, official data showed.

headline: U.S. Brings Diplomacy to Energy Politics
summary: The State Department is creating a Bureau of Energy Resources to focus exclusively on energy, a sign of the growing importance of energy issues to U.S. foreign policy and national security.

headline: India's Iron-Ore Exports to Slump in 2011-12
summary: Exports of iron-ore from India are likely to fall as much as 39% this fiscal year because of supply snags, a senior industry executive said, even as demand from the commodity's main consumer, China, has started to pick up after a two-month slump.

headline: The Sonepur Fair
summary: After the Pushkar Cattle Fair in Rajasthan and the donkey fair in Gujarat, it's time for the Sonepur Fair in Bihar. Some snapshots.

headline: Aditya Birla Explores Bid for New Hope
summary: India's Aditya Birla Group is set to perform due diligence on coal miner New Hope, emerging as a potential bidder in what could be a $5 billion deal.

headline: Indian Oil to Expand Refining Capacity
summary: Indian Oil, the country's largest refiner, plans to raise its group refining capacity by 87% by March 2021, buoyed by demand for fuel products in the world's second-fastest-growing major economy.

headline: Allianz to Raise Dividend Payout Ratio

headline: Greek Economy Slumps as New Government Awaits Aid
summary: The economy contracted at an annualized rate of 5.2% in the third quarter and the downturn is expected to deepen. Without the next EU aid tranche, Greece will run out of cash in December.

headline: Asia Falls on Lingering Troubles in Europe
summary: Asian stock markets ended broadly lower Wednesday as a rise in European sovereign bond yields Tuesday triggered fresh concerns over the euro-zone debt crisis.

headline: Nikko Asset Management to List in Tokyo

headline: The Bachchan Clan

summary: A Kingfisher plane flies above a statue in New Delhi, a fair in Bihar, art installations on the banks of the Yamuna River, and more.

headline: Complex Financial Bets Rise Ahead of Overhaul
summary: The size of the over-the-counter derivatives market rose by 18% in the first half of the year, to a record $708 trillion, according to figures released Tuesday by the Bank for International Settlements.

headline: Behind Plain-Jane Exterior

summary: Leading tech companies including Google and eBay are stepping up efforts to block a bill in Congress that Hollywood studios say would clamp down on foreign websites selling pirated movies and other goods.

summary: As we look at the cost to educate a child, we must not overlook the fact that Catholic schools charge tuition below their cost to educate, and do so without taxpayer support.

summary: Their examples offer hope. But if we expect a seamless transition to modernity, we will be sorely disappointed.

summary: The scandal isn't what they do with their own money, but what they do with ours.

summary: The Army's new acquisition and testing strategy aims to bring new gear to the battlefield quickly, forcing contractors to adjust to a new way of doing business.

summary: Finally, a retrospective that takes David Smith's full career into consideration, revealing the sculptor one critic once predicted would become "the greatest of all American artists."

summary: Landlords to nursing homes are being sent to the sick house by investors who fear that deep cuts in Medicare spending will siphon off rent payments.

summary: Was Obama's decision to delay the Canadian oil pipeline shrewd politics? Maybe not.

summary: The Ultimate Fighting Championship, the largest promoter of mixed martial arts, is suing to overturn New York's ban on live MMA bouts.

summary: Senate leaders struck a tentative agreement on the detention of terrorism suspects, a step that could end a five-month political deadlock and move a stalled defense-spending blueprint toward approval.

headline: ABT's City Center Season Worked Best With Ballet
summary: American Ballet Theatre's fall season reveals how rewarding it is when contemporary works plug directly into what ballet dancers are schooled to do.

headline: Weakness Continues for Design Firms
summary: The Architecture Billings Index climbed in October, posting a score of 49.4, compared with 46.9 in September. Any score above 50 indicates a rise in billings.

summary: By Allysia Finley  Newt Gingrich has staked his campaign on winning Iowa, which would give him momentum going into South Carolina, Nevada, and Florida.

summary: The reductions could include 900 jobs in its securities and banking division, or about 5% of the unit's world-wide staff

summary: A dozen survivors of the January shooting rampage in Tucson, Ariz., that severely wounded Rep. Gabrielle Giffords lobbied federal lawmakers to broaden federal background checks on potential gun owners.

headline: Merkel the Populist
summary: As Europe verges on recession, Germany's center-right government contemplates a job-killing minimum wage.

headline: LinkedIn Seeks to Bolster Shares
summary: LinkedIn is taking steps to try to keep the price of its newly public shares from taking a nose dive next week.

summary: As hula dancing becomes popular on the mainland, some complain the dance is swaying from its traditional roots.

summary: Many people believe a pound of bologna and pound of gold have the same weight.

summary: The Swiss bank's rush to clarify its leadership is understandable given the challenges that UBS faces.

summary: The U.S. Postal Service said it ended another fiscal year with billions of dollars in losses, an expected announcement that continued to illustrate the agency's shaky financial picture.

headline: Protesters Weigh Movement's Future
summary: Occupy Wall Street activists grappled with the future of their movement after a police raid and a day of legal drama ended their hold on a Manhattan park that had become the symbolic center of the world-wide protest.

headline: Facebook Slammed by Porn Attack
summary: Facebook said a "coordinated spam attack" was to blame for the posting of pornographic and violent images on the Web pages of unsuspecting Facebook users.

headline: The $200,000-a-Year Mine Worker
summary: A resources boom is fueling demand for mining labor and has spurred skyrocketing pay. James Dinnison, a 25-year-old high-school dropout from Western Australia, makes $200,000 a year running drills in underground mines.
